title: Identifying the Four Species
why: The Torah’s description of the four species to be taken on Sukkot is sufficiently unclear that it left generations of Jews puzzled over which species they should be.
what: This fanciful early medieval narrative midrash (biblical interpretation) claims that even the wise King Solomon did not know which species they were.
unique_aspect: the ambiguity and complexity in identifying the four species from the Torah, highlighting the persistent quandary in understanding their exact nature and significance. It underscores the wisdom of the Rabbinic sages in interpreting these species as the etrog, lulav, myrtle, and willow.
context: This text is a Midrash, a form of rabbinic literature that explores biblical texts. It discusses the four species (etrog, lulav, myrtle, willow) used during the Jewish festival of Sukkot, highlighting the ambiguity in their identification from the Torah.

title: An Advocate for Rain
why: As a necessary building block of life in ancient Israel, rain is a blessing.
what: This early medieval midrash (biblical interpretation) suggests that it is the day of Shemini Atzeret itself that is an advocate for rain.
unique_aspect: the rabbinic midrashic idea that the day of Shemini Atzeret itself is an advocate for rain.
context: Kohelet Rabbah is a midrashic commentary on the biblical book of Ecclesiastes. This text discusses the concept of Shemini Atzeret, a Jewish holiday that marks the end of Sukkot and is traditionally associated with prayers for rain.

title: The Lulav
why: The lulav is the branch of a date palm, which serves as the “backbone” of the four species, and often refers to the combination of the date palm, myrtle, and willow.
what: The first-millennium mystical work, Sefer HaBahir, explains how elements of the date palm are both masculine and feminine — just as the Torah tells us that God created humans, in God’s own image.
unique_aspect: the mystical symbolism of the four species, particularly the date palm (lulav), by exploring its male and female aspects and linking it to the creation of man and woman in Genesis. It also delves into the spiritual significance of the lulav's internal and external fruits, and their connection to the moon's power.
context: The Sefer HaBahir is a Kabbalistic work from the 12th century. This passage discusses the mystical symbolism of the four species used during the Jewish holiday of Sukkot, particularly the date palm or "lulav".

title: The Reward for Kindling Lights
why: Even though elsewhere the rabbis assert that one should not perform mitzvot (commandments) with the reward in mind, that did not stop them from claiming that there are indeed rewards, even for lighting Sabbath candles.
what: The Babylonian Talmud in tractate Shabbat enumerates the rewards for observing many mitzvot , including the lighting of Sabbath candles.
unique_aspect: the unique concept of receiving rewards for the act of kindling lights on Shabbat and Hanukkah, suggesting that those who perform this mitzvah will have children who are Torah scholars. This is exceptional as it is not common to perform mitzvot with the expectation of reward.
context: how Rav Huna and Rav Hisda observed fathers who were meticulous in lighting many Shabbat candles. Rav Huna predicted that two great scholars would emerge from the family of Rabbi Avin, and Rav Hisda predicted one great scholar would emerge from Rav Sheizvi's family. Their predictions were fulfilled, as the sons and Rav Sheizvi himself became great Torah scholars. This shows an exceptional case where the Sages state that the reward for performing the mitzvah of Shabbat candles is to have children or descendants who are themselves Torah scholars.

title: Four New Years
why: Rosh Hashanah, commonly known as the Jewish New Year, is actually one of four New Years in the Jewish calendar.
what: The Mishnah, the first codification of Jewish law from the early third-century land of Israel, details these four New Years and explains the unique purpose each one serves.
unique_aspect: the concept that there are four different New Years in the Jewish calendar, each serving a unique purpose. It details the significance of each New Year, including the first of Nisan for kings and festivals, the first of Elul for animal tithes, the first of Tishrei for counting years, Sabbatical Years, Jubilee Years, planting, and tithing vegetables, and the first of Shevat for trees. It also highlights that the world is judged at four different times of the year.
context: This text from the Mishnah, a key Jewish legal text, outlines the four New Years in the Jewish calendar, each with a different purpose related to religious observances, such as tithing and festivals.

title: Father of a Nation
why: Abraham, patriarch of the Jewish people, emerged from a world of idolatry and established a covenant with God.
what: The Passover Haggadah’s account of Israel’s descent into Egypt recounts their national origins and frames Jewish history as the fulfillment of that initial covenant between Abraham and God.
unique_aspect: the journey of Abraham from idol worship to monotheism, highlighting his role as the father of the Jewish people and the significance of the covenant between him and God. It also underscores the fulfillment of God's promise to Abraham, marking the end of exile and the birth of the Jewish nation.
context: This text is from the Passover Haggadah, recited during the Seder meal. It emphasizes the journey of the Jewish people from idolatry to monotheism, highlighting Abraham's pivotal role in this transition.

title: Leap of Faith
why: Abraham chooses to abandon his family and his entire world in order to follow God to a land he has never seen.
what: Rashi, the renowned 11th-century northern French biblical commentator, elaborates on the significance of the three parts of God’s promise.
unique_aspect: the depth of Abraham's faith in God, as demonstrated by his willingness to follow God's commands without knowing the end result. It highlights Abraham's obedience and trust in God's promises, even when the specifics of these promises were not immediately revealed to him. This source also underscores the significance of Abraham's name in Jewish prayer, indicating his enduring legacy and influence within the Jewish faith.
context: Rashi's commentary on Genesis 12:2 is a key source in understanding Abraham's faith in God. It discusses the blessings God promised Abraham and their significance, and is often referenced in Jewish studies.

title: The Obligation of Self-Care
why: Caring for one’s own body and soul is not a modern fad but rather a religious obligation.
what: The fifth-century midrashic collection on the book of Leviticus, Vayikra Rabbah, offers three tales of rabbis teaching this lesson to their students.
unique_aspect: the narrative approach to convey the religious obligation of taking care of one's body, using the example of Hillel the Elder's actions and teachings.
context: Vayikra Rabbah 34:3 is a midrashic text, a form of rabbinic literature that provides commentary on the Torah. This particular text emphasizes the religious obligation of self-care, using the narrative of Hillel the Elder as an example.

title: Balancing the Books
why: The Ten Days of Repentance are a period in the Jewish calendar during which some strive to repent past transgressions.
what: The Jerusalem Talmud discusses whether it is God’s judgment of the coming year or of the previous year that is operative during this period.
unique_aspect: the concept of judgement during the Ten Days of Repentance, and the categorization of individuals into three groups: perfectly just, perfectly evil, and average. It highlights the idea that the fate of the average ones is determined during these ten days based on their repentance.
context: This text from the Jerusalem Talmud discusses the concept of divine judgement during the Ten Days of Repentance, a significant period in the Jewish calendar between Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur.

title: Repentance in Egypt
why: Before the people of Israel could be redeemed from Egypt, they needed to repent.
what: The 12th-century Spanish biblical commentator Ibn Ezra explains Israel’s suffering and repentance.
unique_aspect: the biblical example of the Israelites' repentance in Egypt and the subsequent outcome, which led to their freedom from cruel masters.
context: Ibn Ezra's commentary on Exodus 2:23 is a key example of the concept of repentance (Teshuvah) in Jewish biblical interpretation, highlighting the consequences of the Israelites' idolatry in Egypt.

title: The Festival Candles
why: Just as one lights candles to welcome the Sabbath, it is also traditional to light candles at the beginning of holidays, such as Passover or Rosh Hashanah.
what: Rabbi Joseph Karo, the 16th-century author of the authoritative legal code, the Shulchan Arukh, records this requirement.
unique_aspect: the tradition of lighting candles to welcome holidays, specifically Yom Tov, in addition to the Sabbath.
context: The Shulchan Arukh is a 16th-century code of Jewish law. This text refers to the tradition of lighting candles to welcome Jewish holidays, similar to the Sabbath candle lighting.

title: As Many as the Seeds of a Pomegranate
why: On Rosh Hashanah, there is a custom to eat symbolic foods and declare one’s hopes for the coming year.
what: Rabbi Moses Isserles, author of the Mappah, a commentary on the Shulchan Arukh, records and explains the Ashkenazi custom of eating pomegranate seeds on the eve of Rosh Hashanah.
unique_aspect: the symbolic use of pomegranates during the Jewish holiday of Rosh Hashanah, where they are eaten with a prayer that the eater's merits may be as numerous as the seeds of the pomegranate.
context: This text outlines traditional foods and prayers associated with Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, including the custom of eating pomegranates.

title: A Time of Preparation
why: The blowing of the shofar during Elul is an integral part of the spiritual preparation for the High Holidays.
what: The Baal Shem Tov, the 18th-century founder of the Chasidic movement, likens this time of spiritual preparation to preparing to go to battle.
unique_aspect: the role of the shofar during Elul as a call to self-improvement and introspection, particularly for the leaders of the generation. It suggests that if the leaders improve their deeds, they can guide and inspire the rest of the community. However, if the leaders fail to do so, each individual should strive for self-improvement independently.
context: This text is related to the Jewish High Holidays, specifically Rosh Hashana and Yom Kippur. It discusses the tradition of blowing the shofar, a ritual horn, from the first day of Elul as a call for self-improvement and spiritual preparation.

title: Master of Forgiveness
why: Selichot prayers are poetic compositions meant to help us to focus on God’s judgment and mercy.
what: This poem, from the selichot of the Sephardi-Mizrachi liturgical tradition, is an acrostic of the Hebrew alphabet, proclaiming God’s mercy and character traits.
unique_aspect: the detailed enumeration of God's attributes and the repeated plea for mercy, which is a characteristic feature of the genre of Selichot.
context: This text is a Selichot prayer, a penitential prayer recited by Jews in the period leading up to the High Holidays (Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur). It's a plea for forgiveness and mercy.

title: Elul at Sinai
why: What is the historical significance of the month of Elul in the biblical narrative?
what: The medieval midrash Tanchuma offers a timeline of the dramatic events at Sinai, from the giving of the Torah through what would become Yom Kippur.
unique_aspect: the biblical narrative history of the time period of Elul, detailing Moses' journey up and down the mountain, his interactions with God, and the establishment of Yom Kippur as a day of forgiveness and pardon for future generations.
context: The Midrash Tanchuma is a collection of rabbinic homiletic interpretations of the Torah. This particular text recounts the biblical narrative of Moses receiving the Ten Commandments, breaking them, and then receiving them again, which culminates in the establishment of Yom Kippur.

title: If You See a Pomegranate in Your Dreams
why: The rabbis believed in dream interpretation, including if one were to see a pomegranate.
what: In the Babylonian Talmud, at the end of tractate Berakhot, the rabbis recorded the meanings of many symbols one might see in their dreams.
unique_aspect: the symbolic significance of pomegranates appearing in dreams, and how their interpretation can vary based on the dreamer's status as a Torah scholar or an ignoramus.
context: how one who sees pomegranates in a dream, if they were small, his business will flourish like the seeds of the pomegranate, which are numerous; and if they were large, his business will increase like a pomegranate. One who saw slices of pomegranates in his dream, if he is a Torah scholar, he should anticipate Torah, as it is stated: "I would cause you to drink of spiced wine, of the juice of my pomegranate" (Song of Songs 8:2), which is traditionally understood as an allusion to Torah. And if the dreamer is an ignoramus, he should anticipate mitzvot, as it is stated: "Your temples are like a split pomegranate" (Song of Songs 4:3). As the Gemara previously interpreted homiletically: What is the meaning of the word "Your temples [rakatekh]"? Even the most ignorant [reikanin] among you, Israel, are full of mitzvot like a pomegranate.

title: Protecting Both Body and Soul
why: The Torah commands that one both “Look out for yourself and guard your soul exceedingly...”
what: The 16th-century Torah commentary, Kli Yakar, by Rabbi Shlomo Ephraim ben Aaron Luntschitz, answers the question of whether the Torah requires one to be more careful of their body or soul.
unique_aspect: a different interpretation of the verse in Deuteronomy, suggesting that it not only instructs to guard one's physical health but also places a greater emphasis on the protection of one's soul.
context: The Kli Yakar is a 16th-century commentary on the Torah. This text is discussing a verse from Deuteronomy, suggesting a dual focus on physical and spiritual well-being.

title: The First Day of the Seventh Month
why: The Torah does not identify Rosh Hashanah as “Rosh Hashanah.”
what: Rather, it identifies the first of the seventh month as a day on which the horn — namely, the shofar — is sounded.
unique_aspect: the biblical origin of Rosh Hashanah, specifying it as the first day of the seventh month and highlighting it as a day of rest and the sounding of the horn (shofar).
context: the observance of Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish new year, on the first day of the seventh month. It states that this is a sacred occasion on which no work should be done, and "you shall observe it as a day when the horn is sounded." This establishes Rosh Hashanah as the day for sounding the shofar.

title: From the Throne of Judgment to the Throne of Mercy
why: The rabbis explain the power of the shofar to transform God’s justice to mercy and when it is effective.
what: This early medieval midrash makes its argument from a verse from Psalms.
unique_aspect: the transformative power of the shofar, suggesting that when the Jewish people blow the shofar, God transitions from His throne of justice to His throne of mercy, thereby turning justice into mercy for them.
context: The Pesikta DeRav Kahanna is a collection of Aggadic Midrash (interpretive, non-legalistic Jewish texts). This text is often referenced during the High Holidays, when the shofar is blown, symbolizing a call for God's mercy.

title: The Day One’s Fate is Really Sealed
why: Hoshana Rabbah, the seventh day of Sukkot, is a day filled with unique customs, prayers, and rituals.
what: In his fourteenth-century work, Rabbi David Abudarham provides a detailed account of the special prayers, the circling of the ark seven times, and the significance of this day as the actual sealing of the request for life made on Yom Kippur.
unique_aspect: the significance of Hoshana Rabbah as the actual day on which one's judgement is sealed, as opposed to Yom Kippur. It highlights the unique customs and prayers associated with this day, including the addition of specific Psalms and the circling of the ark seven times. It also underscores the theme of water and the beginning of requests for rain in prayers.
context: Hoshana Rabbah, the seventh day of Sukkot, is traditionally viewed as the final day of judgement from the High Holidays. This text reflects the belief that one's fate, initially inscribed on Rosh Hashanah and sealed on Yom Kippur, is delivered on Hoshana Rabbah.

title: The Five Prohibitions of the Day
why: The ancient rabbis identify five central prohibitions for Yom Kippur.
what: The Tosefta, an ancient collection of rabbinic laws and teachings, offers this list.
unique_aspect: the five prohibitions of Yom Kippur: eating, washing, drinking, anointing oneself, and wearing sandals. It also highlights that these prohibitions extend to wearing soft shoes made of cloth and that minors are exempt from these restrictions, except for wearing sandals due to its appearance.
context: This text outlines the five prohibitions observed on Yom Kippur, the holiest day in the Jewish calendar, dedicated to atonement and repentance.

title: Resurrection of the Dead
why: Rain brings life, even to that which is dead.
what: In the 19th-century Ben Ish Chai, Yosef Hayyim of Baghdad presents a mystical interpretation of rain, linking it to spiritual refinement and resurrection of the dead.
unique_aspect: the mystical notion that rain has the power to revive the dead and gather the holy sparks in the inanimate. It also highlights the importance of man's role in refining the living and the vegetative through eating, and the significance of the commandments related to forbidden mixtures and the prohibition of milk and meat.
context: This text is from the Ben Ish Hai, a 19th-century Iraqi rabbi known for blending Halacha (Jewish law) and Kabbalah (Jewish mysticism). It discusses the Kabbalistic concept of refining holy sparks, particularly through the observance of dietary laws.

title: As Wise as a Pomegranate is Full of Seeds
why: The rabbis read the short poetic scroll of Song of Songs, including its mention of a pomegranate, as a metaphor for God’s love for God the Jewish people.
what: Rabbi David Altschuler, an 18th-century biblical commentator, interprets the phrase “like a section of pomegranate.”
unique_aspect: the metaphorical interpretation of the Song of Songs, portraying God's love for Israel. It uses the imagery of a pomegranate to symbolize the wisdom and knowledge of the Sanhedrin, who are likened to the face of the congregation. This wisdom is hidden, much like the seeds of a pomegranate, and is not showcased before others, reflecting the hidden love and desire that is intensified by the veil in the Song of Songs.
context: The Metzudat David is a commentary on the Tanakh, and this excerpt is an interpretation of Song of Songs, often read allegorically in Jewish tradition as expressing the love between God and Israel.

title: Shofar as Alarm
why: Imagine the shofar as an alarm to awaken our souls to self-examination.
what: In Rambam’s monumental 12th-century legal code, the Mishneh Torah, he offers insight into the functions of the shofar.
unique_aspect: the symbolic role of the shofar as an alarm for our souls, urging us to wake up from our spiritual slumber, inspect our deeds, and repent. It highlights the shofar's call as a reminder to remember our Creator and abandon our evil paths and thoughts. It also underscores the importance of performing good deeds and giving to charity, especially from Rosh HaShanah until Yom Kippur, as a means to tip the balance of the world towards merit and bring deliverance and salvation to ourselves and others.
context: This text is from Maimonides' Mishneh Torah, a code of Jewish law. It discusses the significance of the shofar, a ram's horn blown on Rosh HaShanah, the Jewish New Year, and the period of repentance leading up to Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.

title: Share the Joy
why: The Torah commands us to rejoice on Sukkot, but what about the less fortunate in our midst?
what: In Rabbi Isaiah HaLevi Horovitz’s 17th-century work, the Shenei Luchot HaBerit, he explores the concept of joy during Sukkot, emphasizing the importance of extending this joy to the less fortunate.
unique_aspect: the importance of not only personal and familial joy during the holiday of Sukkot, but also the obligation to extend this joy to the less fortunate in society, including strangers, orphans, and widows. It underscores the necessity of sharing the blessings of the holiday with all, as a true reflection of the commanded joy of Sukkot.
context: This text is related to the Jewish holiday of Sukkot, emphasizing the importance of joy and charity during the celebration. It underscores the obligation to not only ensure happiness within one's family, but also among the less fortunate.
